The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Tuesday for the present except the MONGOLIA, which is taking passengers to the Anglo-French Naval Review, and will not wait at Port-Said on 24/25 July. div.head: THE GOVERNMENT'S POSITION
div.p: In the Standing Committee of the House of Commons on Law the Government has sustained what a member described as their third substantial defeat at the bands of their own ardent supporters. The measure under discussion was the Workmen's Compensation Bill, and the Secretary had proposed in the definition clause to exclude from its provisions all shop assistants in shops where less than three are employed. His principle, 80 far as can be gathered from the condensed report of the procəedings, was to make compensation applicable to the big wholesale establishments where heavy balos of goods are handled, but to exclude it from the more modest shops where the employés behind the counter are presumably exposed to fewer risks. This proposal, however, did not in any way commend itself to the demogratio section upon the Committee, and Mr. Seddon, the Radical and Labour member for the Nonton Division of Lancasbire, moved its rejection. Mr. Seddon has himself been a grocer's apprentice, and has served as President of the Shop Assistants' Union, and his argument proved 80 convincing that, in spite of Mr. Gladstone's opposition, the limitation of the Bill to shops where three assistants are employed was detested by 32 votes to 20. The clause, as DOW Amend. ed, brings shop assistants of every degree within the purview of the Act, and introduces « Dew and somewhat disturbing element into the conditions under which the retail trade is carried on. We must confess to certain amount of sympathy with Mr. Seddon. If shop assistants are to be included in th: Bill at all the compromise suggested by the Home Secretary was comprehensible on one ground only, that of conciliating the small shop keepers, who, as a class, are supposed to be traditional Radicals. As presented to the Committee, the clause was a proposterous pieve of class legislation, aimed at the more prosperous and "ospitalistio" elements of the trado. As amended, it will rouso considerable searchings of heart among an important body of the Government supporters,

More important, however, than the barden thus imposed upon the small shopkeeper is the proof which the division affords of Government helplessness in the face of the Radical extremists. This is the third time, w we have already said, that the Government have yielded on points of principle over the Work men's Compensation Bill alone, and Mr. Herbert Gladstone admitted that the Com.' mittee had come to a serious decision, which must cause the Government to consider their position. The shop assistants, however, need be under no apprehension for their recently acquired charter. The Government will give way, as they have always done hitherto, when the Labour members have shown their teeth and made it plain that they monn business. The Home Secretary will have to tread the path which was followed by the Attorney General over the Trade Dispute. Bill, and the Opposition have to sit by powerlessly; if they were afhandred, or even sixty, stronger, Ministers might find their support worth conciliating. As figures actually stand, the Government Colossus is absolutely subservient to those elements in its composition which represent in an extravagant form the Communistic and Socialistic forces of the electorate. We are being practically raled by the extremists among the Labour members, and the Government exists to carry out their beheste. No wonder that there is grembling among the more moderate members on the Ministerial benches. Mr. Gladstone possesses the art of making concessions in so grudging a manner as to leave the applicants unsatisfied and unmollified. He | has given way on this question of the shop assistants, as he formerly yielded over the application of the Bill to small employers, and as to the period during which compensation cannot be claimed. The Labour members merely regard him as a "squeezable," the moderate Ministerialists as the dangerously weak occupant of a most important office...
Globe.

div.head: Maternity Home.
div.p: We should like to appeal to our readers on behalf of the small crècbe just formed at the Maternity Home by its most excellent matron, Mme Antonio, who is doing very good work. The orèche greatly needs a few perambulators to take the infants out from day to day, and any of our readers who possess old perambulators for which they have no further use would being doing the crèche and, through the crèche, the publio a good turn, by handing them over to Mme Antonio.

div.head: New Bathing Station.
div.p: Devotees of sea-bathing in Alexandria--and their name is legion-will welcome the inanga. ration, which takes place to-day, of the new bathing station at Chstby. It is true that the batbs at San Stefano and Mex are all that could be desired, but distance and the time necessary to go to these baths undoubtedly preolude a large number of bathers from indulging in their favourite pastime as often as they otherwise would. The Chstby baths have therefore come to fill a decided want- resort within easy reach of the city, but which at the same time supplies all the desiderata of bathers. Taking a car at the city terminus, you are transported in the space of five mioutes to this newly-erected casino, where the bracing sea a breeze is to be had in all its freshness. A E tramway station has been made almost opposite i the baths, which provide accommodation for d 150 bathers, there being 70 gentlemen's and 80 | ladies' cabins, all airy and open to the sea, The beach is sandy and the depth of water varies from zero to 2 metres on the men's side and to 1) metres on the ladies' side. Between the two sides a large terrape bas been erected where on a buffet has been installed. For those who wish for nothing more than a "blow" in these warm months, the baths will be deoided boon,

Ahmed Paoba Yehis entertained at a tea party yesterday H.E. the Regent, Sir R Wingate Pacha, Msz'oum Pacha, Pakhry Pacha, Abani Paobs, Ghalib Pachs Sardar, Mahmoad Pacha Shukri, and Mastapha Pacha Ibady, Govərnor of Alexandria.
H. E. Hussein Pacha Fakhry, Minister of Public Works, will leave for England next Monday

M. de la Boulinière, French Diplomatic Agent and Consal-General in Cairo, is leaving to-day, via Port Said, for France, where he will spend the summer months. M. Campon, second secretary at the French Agency, will act as Consul-General during his at seuce.
Baron Max Oppenheim left Cairo to-day for Alexandria, where he will embark for Europe. Baron Oppenheim will spend the summer at Obergassel, Germany, returning to Egypt towards the end of October.
Dr. Antoine Comanos Parbai will leave for Europe on the 29th inst.

Dr. Wigham, of Port Said, has just been in cribed as an Avocat Cour d'Appel. Dr. Wigbam, who is an English lawyer of some yaars' standing, purposes, we understand, to practise in the Court of H.B.M.'s Consal General at Port Said.
Baron Max Oppenheim, of the Sudan Administration, left Cairo yesterday, accompanied by his family, for the Lebanon, where they will spend the summer season.

div.head: EXTRAORDINARY SCENE IN THE DUMA. MINISTRY ASKED TO RESIGN
div.p: ST. PETERSBURG, June 22. Duma --The Ministers of Justice and of the Interior made speeches defending the conduct of the police, but were bowled down amid execrations and shouts of murderers, massacremongers, and "Resign" ! A deputy. Prince Urassoff, ex assistant Minister of the Interior, created a sensation in the House by revealing an inflammatory proclamation printed by the Goverment department.
(Reuter) ST. PETERSBURG, June 22.
majority, demanding the resignation of the Ministry and the formation of a Government responsible to the Duma.
(Router) ST. PETERSBURG, June 22. The Dama bas adopted a motion calling for the creation of a responsible Mioistry. (8.) THE UNITED STATES HORRIFIED.

WASHINGTON, June 22. The Senate passed a resolution stating that the people of the United States were borrified at the massacres of the Jews in Russia and extend their hearty sympathy to the bereaved.
(Reuter)

div.head: KING HAAKON'S CORONATION.
div.p: CHRISTIANIA, Jane 22. | King Haakon and Queen Maud were crowned to-day in Trondhjem Cathedral in accordance with the imposing and ancient ceremonial.
The Prince and Princess of Wales and representatives of all States except Sweden were present.

The Bishop of Trondbjem and the Premier, jointly, placed the crown on King Haakon's head, the Ministers of Foreign Affairs, Interior, and War, presenting respectively the sceptre, orb, and unsheathed sword.

Queen Maud was subsequently crowned in a similar manner. Their Majesties were deeply moved. The President of the Storthing, at the conclusion of the ceremony, called out "God save the King and Queen," and the whole assembly joined with him. (Reuter)
LONDON, Jone 22. King Edward ordered the bells to be rong E at Windsor in honour of the Coronation of the King and Queen of Norway. Salates were fired in many places throughout the United Kingdom.
(Reuter)
TRONDHJEM, June 22. The coronation of King Haakon was very imposing,

div.head: SOUTH AFRICAN DIFFICULTIES.
div.p: SPEECH BY MR. CHURCHILL.

LONDON, June 22. Mr. Churchill, at a banquet at the New Reform Club, dwelt on the necessity of dealing cautiously with the South Africa difficulties and of immediately abolishing Chinese labour. He appealed to Liberals for the continuance of their confidence in view of the imminence of the granting of a responsible government to the Transvaal and the necessity for preventing & violent economic collapse meanwhile.
Sic M. West Ridgeway's Transvaal and Orangia Constitution committee has concluded its labours.
(Reuter)

div.p: London, June 23. The Anglo-German Friendship Committee entertained the German editors at a banquet. Lord Avebury presided. Mr. Loraburn proposed the toast of Anglo-German friendship. The speakers included Mr. Bryce. (Reuter)

div.head: THE DENISHWAI AFFAIR.
div.p: Me. Helbawi Bey and Mr. Moberly have left Cairo for Denishwai, and will examine the locality where the affair took place in the course of to-day. The number of witnesses for the prosecution amounts to 29, including the British officers, their driver, and their guide The total number of accused is 59, of whom eight are still at large.
One Equadron of the 6th (Inniskilling) Dragoons and a detachment of the M.M.P. left Abbassieh at 7 20 a.m. to day for Chibin-el-Kom to be present doring the trial.

The officers of the Mounted latentry company paid a visit to Sheikh Ali Maklad of Kamsbeesh on the 20th inst. and took tea with the sheikh, whose son, Mohamed Ali, made a speech of a very complimentary Datore, emphasi-ing the remarkable restraint shown by the troops and their officers after the Denishwai incident and regretting that strangers should have been so cruelly treated by an ignorant mob. The commanding officer of the company returned thanks to the sheikh for his kindness and courtesy. The mamour of Tala was present at the function.

div.head: THE ABYSSINIAN FRONTIER.
div.p: We hear that by an arrangement with the Abyssinian Government the column which recently left Kassala in porsuit of Hailo Miriam was permitted to cross the Abyssinan frontier at Umrage, near the Bahr es Salam and Augereb rivers, and advance to Mar Gabta, some 40 miles within Abyssinian territory.

Here the column met the Dedjszmatoh (commander of the right wing) Gagsassa, who had encountered and slain Hailo Miriam and restored 40 captives. The Abyssinians are busily bunting up the remainder of the band and hope to be able to restore all the prisoners in the near future.

div.head: NEGLECTED HELOUAN.
PETITION TO THE PREMIER
div.p: Nagaib Bey Sbakrs, advocate and proprietor of the 'Istiklal" magazine, Cairo, sends as copy of a petition which he sabmitted yester day to the President of the Council of Ministera, on behalf of the inhabitants of Helouan.

The petition se's forth that whilomanyimprovements have teen made during the last five years in Cairo and the neighbouring distriots, even in the desert, Helogan, which is one of the most beautiful towns of Egypt, is still greatly in need of improvement.

The petitioner asserts that the Helosan branch of the Delta Light Railway is still in a very defective condition. There is a great difference, he says, in every respe st, between this line and the Matarieh railway. It is true that the latter belongs to the State Railway Administration, which spares no effort to keep its trains and stations in good order, but the Government can compel the Delta Light Railway Company to either improve its Helouan line or give up its concession.
After pointing out that people find great diffioulties in travelling from Cairo to Helonan and vioe-versa, Sbakra Bey, on bebalf of the people of Helouan, makes the following requests :
1. That the railway line between Bab elLook, Cairo, and Helouan should be doubled and arrangements made for one train to leave every 30 minutes; or that trams should replace trains.
2. To bring the Heloaan line ap to the | standard of tha Matarieb railway in material, rolling-stook and personnel.

3. To construot two roads for motor cars at Helouan, one to the Nile and the other to the foot of the mountain ; which scheme might be undertaken by a company composed of some of the chief land-owners of Helouan, if the Government would not enter apon it.
4. If the Delta Light Railway Company refuses to carry out the required improvements the Government will have to purchase its Helouan line and place it under the State Railway Administration.

We should like to poʻnt out that the Helonan line, while still in need of improvement, is in al far better condition than two years ago. As for Shakra Bay's suggestion that a train should leave for Helouan overy half-hour, we have little doubt that the financial result of such an alteration of the time-table would be decidedly | unplexadt. Halosan is, after all, not large town, the passenger traffi) falls off in sommer, and the goods traffic is not very important. As for the "motor-roads," how are they to pay ! Will the bypothetioal company levy tolls on motors, or how will it reimburse itself for the expenses of construction ? The petitioner does not seem to as to have weighed the financial consequences of his proposals.

div.head: NOCTURNAL ARREST.
div.p: * EXCITING CHASE IN CAIRO.
We bave received the following communication from a correspondent in Cairo :

Yesterday morning, at about 3 o'clock, an | Englishman was returbing from a bachelor's dinner and bridge party, and on passing the Sharia Madabogh, close to the now premises of Messrs. Walker and Meimarachi, be noticed a number of suspicious characters loitering round.
Anticipating some fun, our informant waited in a dark cort er for developments in the hope of perhaps assisting in the capture of some noted Anarchist or more probably a raid on a gambling hell.

His patience was rewarded eventually: the too conspicuous detectives (sic) almost imme diately stopped a native lady who resembled the foolish virgins in not having her lamp barning, and after submitting ber to a close examination, possibly to see it she possessed any bombs, she was allowed to proceed. Scarcely bad she proceeded 50 yards, however, befora there was a cry of "imaikoa" |(equivalent to "Stop thief") and the whole posse of detectives started rapning down the street towards Sharia Boulac with, naturally, the Englishman in hot pursuit.

The chase, however, was not organised for the benefit of the lady, as might be presamed by our foregoing remarks. The "eagle eye" | of the secret service had unearthed a suspected criminal, or Anarchist, heaven knows from where, and as the quarry had 'gone away" as smartly as any Reynard from cover, the posse went off like hounds on a hot scent.

Our friend the Englishman dropped out at the first lap and finding a carriage immediate ly opposite the English Church followed up the chase to the building in course of constraction behind the Egyptian telegraph offices in the Sharia Boolse: the name of the driver of the carriage was Said Ahmed Ali, his number 3892, ant the number of his cab 1077. The pursued was run to earth in the chantiers" | already mentioned and our informant arrived in time to see him bandled into a cab with three lasty guardians who showed scant courtesy; as a matter of fact one was dietinctly heard to ask for a rope !

No sooner had our Englishman arrived on the scene than he way surrounded by that part of the posse who ware not occupied with the supposed oriminal and promptly arrested with out any enquiry, - a respectably dressed Bng. Jishman, who spoke Italian and Arabic too well to allow for the momeat the idea of any misunderstanding, was arrested by a crowd of | ignorant secret service agents. He was bundled into his own c.b again with ghuffi No. 10 of ba Ismailia quarter gripping his right wrist in a totally uncalled-for manner and a police spy named Mohamed Sadik on the left. Towering over him was a Baropean, seemingly Maltese, whose name was unobtainable. The manner in which our inform unt was handled was too rough for words: he says his fighting weight is 9 stone 6, so it is difficult to imagine wby three strong men should be required to hold him, more particularly as he did not resist in the slightest, well knowing that he could easily clear himself of any complicity with the fagitive. As a matter of fact the victim is still feeling the results of his rough bandling, although it is jast to say he was not truck. "

On arriving at the Abdəea caracol our informant presented his card to the officer on duty and immediately received from that gentleman the greatest courtesy : the supposed criminal was asked if he knew the Englishman and promptly disclaimed any knowledge of having seen him before. Our friend the Britisher, who is a very peppery individual, then started roundly rating the whole assembly and insisted on immediate release, which was strongly opposed by the Maltese gentleman, but thanks to the courtesy of the officer in charge of the caracol he was permitted to depart. He was, however obliged to pay himself for the carriage in which he had been so roughly bundled.

A fall explanation and complete satistaetion for this outrage would feem to be necessary : that a law abiding person, only too anxious to be of assistance to the police, and manifesting a perfectly legitimate curiosity during an excit|ing occurence, should be arrested without the | slightest chance of justification and handled

like a felon by an ill-conditioned band of so-called secret police is intolerable, and despite our duty to assist in opholding a public body we are compelled to criticise the action of the police in this matter. The gentleman from whom we have this complaint | is a member of the Press and desires a fall enquiry into the matter. One thing is pretty certain, that had be not defended himself very vigorously (with his tongue), he would be at the present moment in "durance

We should like to point out that while the agents of the secret police appear to have grossly expeeded their powers, & gentleman who indulged in games of hide and seek round dark corners at 2 a.m. in London or Paris, and joined anasked in the pursuit of a fogi. tive, would ran considerable risk of passing the night in the "lock-up," and the moral in our opinion is, when returning from a bachelor's party at 2 a.m.: GO STRAIGHT HOME, and remember the ancient proverb 'Curiosity killed the cat.'"

div.head: ARMY AND NAVY.
div.p: Lieutenant Colonel and Brovat Colonel 8t. G. Henry, C.B., the A 'jatant General of the Bgyptian Army, has been granted the sa batantive rank of colonel.

Major W. 8. R. May, Bast Yorkshire Regi. ment, latterly serving with the Egyptian Army, has gone on retired pay. He joined the gallant "Snappers" in May, 1885, wao promoted captain in 1893, major in 1904, and was employed with the Egyptian Army for the past seven years. He saw service in the Nile Expedition of 1899 (medal with clasp)
Captain Gardner, Royal Pasiliers, has been formally seconded for servica with the Kbedive's army.

The 1st Battalion Royal Ioniskilling Fasiliers, Belfast, will troop the colours on Monday next in commemoration of the glorious part the old 27th Inniskillings played in the ever-memorable battle of Waterloo. The officers will give a dance the following evening. The 27th was distingaished at Waterloo by its heroio endurance in a hell of fire," and its terrible losses in killed and woanded.

The 2nd Battalion Leicestershire Regiment, Brevet Colonel E.R. Scott commanding, which go3g from Colchester to India next trooping Season, was last in "The Shiny" from 1876 to 1898, the two sacoeeding years being spont in Barmsh and Aden. It went from Ireland to Bgypt in 1900, and came home in the latter end of 1992. Its 1st Battalion, now at Belgaum, will return home in turn this coming relief 8888on. It was in South Africa when the Boer War broke out, and shared a gallant part in | the defence of Ladysmith and the actions of
Tulana Hill and Lombard's Kop, which preceded the investment of that place.

It is authoritatively stated that the new army scheme, the full details of which will be given by Mr. Haldane next month, will include provision for the long-talked-of territorial army for home defence, and a foreign service army for duty in India, Egypt and the Colonies. The army as it stands will be redece by 43 rogalar batteries of horse and field artillery, and these will be replaced by militia batteries, which necessarily must be able to go on foreiga sørvice if required to do so; the infantry will be reduced by 10,000 men, and the Army Service Corps by twenty companies. The volunteerr, yeomanry, and militia will be consolidatedan utter impossibility to anyone who understands anything about the personnel of those bodies—and a reduction will be made in the strength of the yeomanry. In short, the scheme, so far as is known about it, is a re-bash of some of Mr. Arnold Forster's fads, with nothing to recommend it, save a false sconomy. The outlook of those who will suffer in pay and promotion is by no means reassaring.

It appears that the now 18-pounder field gan has a tendency to turc tartle" under certain conditions owing to the centre of gravity being considerably above the axle. This in turn is due to the peouliar construction of the gun and the recoil apparatus. On broken ground, when palled round suddenly, the gun inolines to topple over, and several nasty spills hsve resalted at Tidworth and elsewhere one case being very unfortanately attended by fatal resulta. Oa active service this woald be a very serious matter. Experts of the Ordnance Dapartment are inquiring into the defect. It is officially stated thist out of the 150 field batteries now on the establishment only 109 will be equipped with the new field gon, whilst 21 of the existing 38 batteries of the Royal Horse Artillery will receive the new 13-pounder. la artillery circle, the threatened reduction of the Royal Regiment is bitterly resented, and condemned.
The programme for the building of several battleships of the Dreadnought type is to be oat dowo, for the sake of economy.

div.head: THE ASSYRIAN CHRISTIANS.
div.p: The annual meeting of the Archbishop's Mission to the Assyrian Christians was held last week in the library of Lambeth Palace.

The Archbishop of Canterbury, who presided, said that this mission in the mountains of Kurdistan had been worked for 20 years with marked SOCCERS. The position of these Christians, oppre sed for centuries, but still holding their faith, was pathetic. The devoted band of belpers sent from the Church of England, picked men of high calibre, were standing by the side of the young Patriarch, teaching him and his people and belping them to make their Christian faith desper, more intelligent, and more practical. An idea of the strangely disturbed state of that Turco Persian borderland might be gathered from a recent incident He had asked the missionsries on both sides of the frontier to meet for counsel; but this bad been found impossible. Letters could pass between them, with some difficulty, but the authorities regarded the region as so dangerou, and were so anxious to avoid the complications which might | follow a disaster, that they would not allow missionaries to cross the mountains. Such difficoltier should make people at home realize more and more the absolute nepersity of maintaining the work, and at a high level.

Lord Perey, M.P., said that a good deal of criticism and abuse had been direeted Against the Christians in the Esst, but some of it had been undeservad, and be preferred to dwell on their good pointe rather than on their faults. Only two Christian races in the Turkish Empire bad been left with more or less complete autonomy, and one of these was the community with which this mission was concerned. The Catholicos, whose geest be had been fira or six years ago, wax res. ponsible for civil as well as ecc'esiastical government. Th, Tarkish authorities at Van might have taken advantage of this ruler's youth if they had meant misobief, but they had given him frank and loyal support. On the Persian side, the state of insecurity was a real repronch to be Persian Government, Now that an agreement for delimitation bad tsen reached, be hoped the two Governments would see their way to do as bad been done on the Indo-Afghan frontier, and make some satisfactory arrangements for the policing of their respective territories. This mission made Do attempt to convert Mohamedans to Chris tianity. He did not believe such attempts were bopeless, bat be doubtod whether they would succeed through the agenoy of Western Church. The East had not always offered the same opposition to Christianity ; bat from the time of the Crusaders the preaching of Christianity had been associated, in the minds of Eastern Governments, with political designe.
Dr. Weitbrecht and the Rev. F. 8. Heazell also addressed the meeting.

The leaders of the mission, in their annual report to the Archbishop, which is about to be issued, state that the ansettled state of the frontier has prevent their castomary visitation of the villages ; while the collapse of the Rassian Government and the increasing poverty of Persia have caused general distress and unrest among Christians and Moslems alike. In Tengawan the work had been almost stopped, owing to the failare of the Persian Government to give satisfaction to the United State for the murder of Mr. Labaree by Kurde two years ago. There had been recently a marked freedom from violence | and robbery, due to the firmness of the Nizam es Saltaneh, who was appointed Governor General at Tabriz during the absence of the Crown Prinos in Teberan, and Jao to the tact and strength of Tan Koli Mirza, who bad been Governor of Urmi since February, 1905, and who had promptly quelled an apti Jewish riot. The Moslems appeared more pacifio than usual. Their contentment had been inorkased by the return of the chief Mollah of Urmi, Mirza Hosein Agbs, whose banishment was obtained by the British Legation last March on account of his intimacy with the murderers of Mr. Labaree. He had returned by the definite permission of the British Minister, and seemed to remember nothing but th: kindness which allowed him to retom. Another matter in which our Legation had been interestad was the protec tion of Mejde Saltaneb, who did his duty in trying to fix the guilt of the murder on the real culprits, and consequently fell under the Crown Prince's displeasure. For four months be remained in the Consalate at Tabriz, until he received permission to leave the country, having arranged that his property should be administered by an English merchant at Tabriz. All attempts to punish the murder ers had come to nothing, the Kurds refusing to give up the colprite, and the Persian Government, in the anoertain state of the frontier, declining to use force. The poverty of the people had been considerable, and business was almost at a standstill. The merchants were inclined to blame the Castomhouse as much as the disastrous state of things in Russia, and there had been a9veral demonstrations against the Belgian admi nistration of the former. The barvest had been very bad, and wheat had risen to three or fcur times its normal price. The Anarchy in Rassia bad preveute i hundreds, if not thousands, from finding work tbere. The Syrians bad now largely ceased to regard the mission of the Russian Church with either hype or respect, and many of its adherents bad left it. The British and Prench missions were on cordial terms, and had been so even before the entente cordiale. An unfortapate festore of the situation was the multiplication of small missions, or rather of individuals of Syrjau birth who had been to America or Barope and retarned to carry on some kind of so called missionary work with a salary paid by friends in those countries.

div.head: UM RUS GOLD MINES,
SHAREHOLDERS SANCTION RECONSTRUCTION OF THE COMPANY.
div.p: The third ordinary general meeting of the members of the Um Ros Gold Mines of Egypt, Limited, was held on the 12th June, 1906, at the Cannon Street Hotel, E.C., Mr. Jobn Harvey, J.P., D.L., (the chairman of the compary) presiding.
The Secretary (Mr. G. H. Welle) read the potice calling the meeting and the auditors'

The Chairman: I should like to explain, with reference to the accounta, that we have to a great extent been the victims of circumstance. These accounts ought strictly, in accordance with the articles of Assosiation, to have been made up to December 31st, 1905, bat owing to the illness of the accountants we have not been able to give them definitely beyond July 31st. This morning we have bad the socounts up to the end of September, and look for the balance sheet in a very short time. We have made an estimate si near as we could possibly oalculate of what the expenditure op to Degember 31st would be, and if you look at the accounts you will see, op page 16, that the expenditare from date of commanding orosbing-vz., March 6th, 1905, to Jaly 3let, 1906 --*a9 £7,189, and we estimate that the cont for the following six months will be about £8,000. Taking that into consideration, as well as the returns of the gold, the actual loss to be made will be about £400, and not more. We were also inconvenienced by part of the electrie msohinery breaking down and delay ing the development for some months, otherwise the development would have shown moob better in these accounts than it does. Had the promise at the opening up of these mines, when we began crushing, hold good, we should not have asked you here to consider a scheme for reconstruction. Mr. Robert Taylor will tell you by and bye as to the average yield of the gold ap to date. If you look at the accounts you will see that, whereas we started with a reserve of 9,000 tons, on April 15th it was inoressed ap to 10,000 tone, and, as I said before, that would have been materially incre used had it not been for the failure of part of the machinery. Mr. Llewellyo, who probably bas had more experience of the mines and the grld-bearing districts of Egypt than anyone, is here to day, and he will be able to give his impressions with regard to the mines. If any of the shareholders would like to pat any ques tions, I shall be very happy to answer them to the best of my ability, and in the meantime I propose : - "That the report and socounts, as submitte1, be received and adopted."
Sir Henry Banbury, Bart., seconded the refolution.

Mr. Robert Taylor said that the development work bad proceeded regularly at the mine throughout the year ander review. Thedistances in shaft sinking, driving levels and cross-oatting, and in win 28 and rises had altogether amounted to 3,000 ft. This being added to the develop mente previously accomplished made a total of 6,900 ft, or one and a third miles since the commencement of operations. Daring the year the main shaft bad been sank 100 ft. making its present total depth 625 ft. The result of fatore work at the deepest levels from the main shaft and the driving of the 450 ft., level north-east from that shaft would be watched with mach interest, but it was to the satisfactory developments in the neighbourhood of the western shaft to which they would now. specially look. The mine in that section was opening up in most promising way, and the resalts obtained during the last four or five months in partioular fully confirmed the views that there was a valuable reef to be followed, and that the indications fally war ranted the continuance of vigorous work. (Hear, beer.) During the last 15 months 9,890 tons of ore had been milled, producing 6,900 ozs of gold, of a value of £1,270, which was certainly so encouraging commencement and there remained 10,000 tons of ore standing in reserve in the mine. It was satisfactory to find that the result of the milling received yesterday---Monday-by cablegram from the mine, for the 18 daye ron during the month of May, showed that the gold obtained was rather more than that of the previous month, and that the yield per ton was 2 dwts higher. (Hear, hear.) The capital proposed to be raised by the organisation of the company would permit of a larger scale of operations, and now that a muob bigber rate of speed in working had been established by the use of rock drills, they confidently looked forward to more rapid development, and to placing the mine in a condition to substantially increase the output of quartz

Mr. Arthur Llewellyn: Gentlemen, I recently visited the Um Ros Gold Mines for the purpose of making a technical report, and that being the case your directors have considered that a few words from me might perhaps be of service in assisting you to decide whether or not you should go through with Me reconstruction scheme. Perconally, I may say I am entirely in favour of it, and from the day of my first examination of the mine I have never had & moment's doobt that its conditions and Drospects fally justified me in recommending to your board a forward policy and the employ ment of additional capital to carry on the work. As you are all doubtless aware, the first drivages from the main shaft opened up a sur prisingly good reef, and had this continued it is unnecessary for me to tell you tbat your position to-day would have been a very different one. Subsequent developments have, by contrast,

been somewhat disappoiating, but this is Junally the care in vein mining, and I must ask you pot to take too gloomy a view of the present situation, or to permit yourselves to consider that, althongh recent developments have been somewhat disappointing, and not up to their previous high average, they have gone to the opposite extreme, or been in the main valueless. I may say that the contrary is the case. If you refer to the plan and gretion at the end of the report, and draw a straight line from the extremities of the 245 ft-th9 apper level sbown on the section to the bottom of the 550 ft winzy, you will describe a a triangle, whieb, with the addition of a dar row strip above the 245 ft, includes the portion of the reef qpened up by your present mining work. The area of this portion is roughly 6,000 square tathom, and taking the average th'ck ness of the reef at i ft 6 ins, this shonld give you a total mineral contents of 24 000 tons. Now, what proportion of this 24,000 tons is considered by your engineers to be of workable valne ! If you refer to page 33 of the report you will find that 8,000 tons have been already milled, while the remaining reserves are estim ated at 10,000 tons. This means that no lese than three-fourths of the whole of the contents of that portion of the reef hitherto developed are considered by your engineers to be of milling value and I think that most men will admit that this is an apurually large propor. tion. It is not rich, but it is good fair-milling ore ; but events have proved that, when treated on the moderate scale hitherto possible, it is not sofficiently rich to be treated at a profit. If you were in position to increase the output of the mine, and to donble the tonnage of the ore sent to the mill, I be'ieve the mine could be profitably worked, but to enable you to do this it is ne 388sary that the mine should be further developed and a grester area of ground laid open for stoping, and it is with the object of carrying this poligy into effect | that the present scheme of reconstruction is now placed before you.

Mr. Delisa draw attention to the question of the administration expenses, and expressed the hope that, should the reconstruction be Garried throagh, as he had no doubt it would be, the directors would do their utmost to economise in that direction in every possible way. He also expressed the hope that the management would be able to see their way to getting more than 18 days work per month ont of the plant.

Tha Chairman, in reply, said that he could not very well see that it was possible to reduce the administrative charges, and in connection with the directors' fees he might mention that Mr. Robert Taylor did not draw directors' fees. He pointed out that it was impossible to get competent and reliable officials to go out to Egypt and carry on the work at their mines upless they were ade quately paid. With reference to the item of depreciation to which attention had bean calle 1 by one of the shareholders, he explained that that item had reference to the steamor which they had out in Egypt. It was al. ways advisable to write off a certain amount for depreciation in connection with that steamer, and he might also mention that it was alwaye advisable to write off a certain amount from their machinery and plant.
The revolution was then put to the meeting and carried unanimously.
Ir. John Taylor proposed that the retiring directors, Messrs. John Harvey and Vere Herbert Smith, be re-elected

The auditors, Messrs. Deloitte, Plender, Griffiths and Co., having been resppointed, an extraordinary general meeting of the company was then bald to consider the resolutions to wind up the company voluntarily, with a view to its being reconstructed.
The Secretary having read the notice of the extraordinary general meeting,
The Chairman moved the adoption of the resolutions on the notice paper.
Mr. Vere Herbert Smith seconded the reaola tions, and they were carried
The proceeding4 then terminate l with a vote of thanks to the chairman.

div.head: THE AMERICAN PURE FOOD LAW.
div.p: The "Times" has received an advance proof of an important and interestiog article by Mr. J. Wilbe force Green on the law dealing | with the adulteration of food in Amerio, which will appear in tha forthcoming number of the British Food Journal" :

The American Pure Pood Act (says the writer), which passed the United States Senate on February 21 list, is "an Act for preventing be adulteration or misbranding of foods or droge, and for regulating traffic therein, ard for other purposes," and is the latest import ant measure that has been passed with the idea of limiting, as far as possible, in extent, and modifying in cbaracter, the adulteration of food products and draga.

He then points out that, contrary to what might bave been expected in a country so rich in resources and comparatively 80 thinly populated, competition and the great advances in chemistry, which apable manufacturers to escape detection, have made the prevalence of food adulteration in the United States very considerable :

In these circumstances the scruples which we may charitably suppose to have existed in the minds of the directors of many large manufacturing concerns have rapidly disappeared, and sach "foods" as golden syrup, consisting of starch-glucose, fruit jelly contain ing anything but fruit juice and coloured with ooal-tar dyes, lard consisting of beef stearin, and cottonseed oil "filled" cheesar, and so forth, have been put upon the market. Some years ago the United States Secretary of Agricultore estimated that "aboot 80 per cent. in value of all the food prodacts in the United States were either adulterated or misbranded." To be on the safe side he subsequently halved the above figure, but even on a 15 per cent. basis, the amount of the misbranded and adalterated articles that went into commeros every year represented $ 1,175,000,000 (£235,000,000), and at the present time it is placed at $3,000,000,000 (£600,000,000).

The Pare Food Act, being « Federal Act, bas regard only to the external or transit trade ; and thus, while it does not affect the nternal trade of the individual Staten, it is iof special interest to Great Britain, since its provisions regalate the conditions under which American foods are imported into Great Britain. It is therefore, important to learn that:

In the last part of section I. of the Act the following words coeur :-"That no article shall be deemed misbranded or adulterated within the provisions of this Act when intened for export to any foreign country, and prepared or packed according to the specifixation or directions of the foreigo parohaser when no substance is used in the preparation or packing thereof in conflict with the laws of the foreign country to which said article is intended to be shipped." The practical interest in this section so far as this country is concerned is found in the words quoted and italicited above. In the discussion on the Pare Pood Bill of January 16 last Senator Moumber observed that :"Most of the bams that are shipped out of the country are shipped to Great Britain. There is no prohibition in the food laws of Great Britain against the age of borax as a packing ingredient." In Subsection 5 it is stated that a food shall be deemed to be adulterated "fit contain any added poisonous or other added deleterious ingredient which may render such article injarious to health. Provided, that when in the preparation of food products for shipment they are preserved by an external application applied in saob manner that the preservative is necessarily removed mechanioslly, or by maceration in water, or otherwise, the provisions of this Act shall be construed as applying only whan said products are ready for consumption." By this sabsection all benefit that we might hope to derive in this country from the passing of this Act is completely removed. The Act calmly contemplates the addition to food products of substances that may be either actively poisonous or at least injurious to health, and so long as those substances can be removed, no matter by what means, the United States exporter cannot be touched by his law; Dor, as we well koow, can the importer, wholesale dealer, or retailer on this side be adequately intertered with by ours.

Bat this is not all the evil. Since the United States Legislature intends to prevent the adulteration of food producte within the oyuntry, the large manufacturing firms will be seriously hampered, and will incor, heavy losses :

Their way out of the difficulty will probably be either to "damp" large quantities of cheap, semi-artificial toode on our markets, or to start factories of their own in this country. When the laws connected with the manufature and sale of butter substitutes were made more stringent in the United States some of the United States manufacturers equipped facto ries in Canada, and began the manufacture of "process batter" there. The Canadian Parliament, however, with a very proper regard for the fatore reputation of its dairy industry, at once strengthened its lawa. The manufaoture of procase batter thereby became illegal in the Dominion and cessed forth with.

Sach legislation, Mr. Green adde, is onforto nately less likely to be readily accepted in this country, where the food supply is largely inflaenced by interested persons, who will be quick to declare that restrictive legislation would deprive th community of their cheap food.

div.head: Circulaire H. De Vries et Boutigny
div.p: NOTES ET CRITIQUES

Le Caire, Vendredi 22 Juin 1906. Les télégrammes de Londres portent que la Banque d'Angleterre a réduit hier son taux d'escompte de 4 à 3 1/2 pour cent. Cette mesure, qu'on osait à peine espérer il y a quel ques jours, montre que la situation monétaire s'est finalement détendue. Elle est appelée à exercer une bonne influence sur le marché des valeurs.

En attendant, le taux de l'escompte libre est toujours à 3 1/4 pour cent. Hier, le Consolidé anglais est resté invarié à 88 3/4. L'Unifiée a clôturé en hausse de 1/8 à 104 7/8. La Natio nal Bank a égalemement gagné 1/8 à 25 3/4. L'Agricole est demeurée inchangée à 9 5/8, de même que la Daïrs à 17 1/8 et la Delta Light à 11 3/4.
A Paris, l'action Crédit Foncier Egyptien a regagné 4 franes à 772. La Banque d'Athène réactionné de 1 franc à 154.

lei, nous avons en, ce matin, un marché calme, avec des affaires assez restreintes, mais avec une tendance générale plutôt ferme. Aussi C prévoit-on des séances meilleures pour la se maine prochair e.
La National Bank á gagné 1/16. L'Agricole ! s'est raffermie à 9 11/16-3/4.
Le Crédit Foncier s'est maintenu à 771. La I Dairs a quelque peu molli à 17 1/16, ainsi que e la Bébérs à 36 1/4.

La Nile Land a avancé de 13 1/4 13 3/4. 1 L'Héliopolis s'est traitée à 289. L'Improve 1 ment Corporation a été négociée à 4 9/16-5/8. Toujours en bonne tendance, l'action Entre- prises Immobilières et Travaux a été recher- chée à 4 1/16; la part de fondatear a clôturé 64-65.
Les actions privilégiées Tramways d'Alex- andrie ont réactionné à 192.

Les Omnibus da Caire ont été offerts à 23. L'action Menzsleh a progressé à 4. L'An glo-American Nile a, par contre, faibli à 5 1/8 Dans le groupe des Hôtels, les Nungovich ont fléchi à 15 7/16-1/2 l'action ancienne et 15 3/8 la nouvelle. Les Baebler, très soutenus, ont débuté à 5 1/2 pour avancer à 5 9/16-5/8.

Parmi les petites valeurs, la Delta Land a progressé à 3 7/8 et les Estates à 1 23/32. Les New Egyptian ont été ramenée à 28 sb. 9, les Salt and Soda à 20 sh. 3, les Spinning à 0 7/8 15/16, les Egyptian Constructions à 11/8-3/16, les Nile Cold Storage à 0 7/16 et les Sucreries 26-27.
L'assemblée générale ordinaire de la Compa gnie Agricole du Nil est fixée en 17 Juillet pro chain, au siège social à Anvers, à la Banque de Reports, de Fonds publics et de Dépôts.
A l'ordre du jour: rapport du Conseil, appro- bation des comptes et bilan de l'exercice 1905- 1906, fixation du dividende.
Les actionnaires de la Société Anonyme Egyptienne d'Electricité sont convoqués en as- emblée générale ordinaire pour le 17 Juillet,au siège social à Alexandrie.
A l'ordre du jour: rapport du conseil ; pré- sentation des comptes; élection d'administra tears; nominations statutaires.

Nous prions instamment les personnes qui ne recevraient pas régulièrement notre Circulaire de nous aviser sans retard, afin que nous pai- ssions prendre des mesures immédiates pour assurer la ponctualité du service d'expéditior. Carnet de l'actionnaire.

Un avis de l'Egyptian Improvements Corpo- ration informe les actionnaires en retard que le versement du 4ème quart, soit £1 par titre, est exigible depuis le 15 Avril dernier et que les Nos des actions qui n'auront pas été libé- rées avant le 30 Jain courant seront publiés conformément à l'art. 7 des Statuts et aux fins prévues par cet article.
Commercial & Financial Supplement
OF THE
"Egyptian Gazette.

The Commercial and Financial Supplement of the "Egyptian Gezette" is published at midday every Saturday in time for the Austrian Lloyd's mail. The supplement contains exhaust- ive and important reviews of the cottor, cotton seed, and stock and share market, with all the latest statistics up to the evening of the preceding day, complete tabular forms of the varions market fluctuations, and the copies of the official telegrams of the Liverpool Cotton Association, etc., etc. Subscription for one year P.T. 100 (inclusive of postage in Egypt. For abroad the postage is P.T. 10 extra). For further particulars apply to the Manager "Egyptian Ganette."

div.head: THE STANDARD LIFE ASSURANCE CO.
ESTABLISHED 1825.
div.p: ACCUMULATED FUNDS £11,750,000.
NEW SCHEMES OF ASSURANCE.
ENDOWMENT ASSURANCES with guaranteed bonus on survival of 2 per annum for each 100 of assurance.
CHILDREN'S ENDOWMENTS at low rates, with return of all premiums paid in the event of death before the given age is attained.
EXAMPLES:

ENDOWMENT ASSURANCES WITH GUARANTEED BONUS ON SURVIVAL.-A, aged 30 next birthday, with Good prospect of longevity, takes out a Policy of £1,000 under this table for an Endowment Assurance payable at the age of 60 or earlier death, with a Guaranteed Bonus of 40s. per cent per annum. If he survives the fixed term, the annual premium for which will be £38:15:0. In the event of death within the 30 yearsm only the sum assured in the Policy is payable, viz:- £1,000, but if he survives the term, he is entitled to receive besides £1,000, a Guaranteed Bonus of 30 times 40s. per cent; i.c. £800, or in all £600; and similarly for other periods and rates, Premiums can be paid quarterly or half-yearly if desired.

CHILDREN'S ENDOWMENT.- An annual Premium of £18:1:3 will provide a child aged 1 next birthday with an Endowment of £500 on attaining the age of 21. In the event of the child's death before the given age is attained, all the premiums paid to the Company will be return to the parent. Premiums can be paid quarterly or half-yearly if desired. Should the parent wish to discontinue the payment of premiums, he can claim a surrender value of 90 per cent of all the annual premiums paid by him, excepting the first, providing three full years premiums have been paid and the transaction is completed while the Policy is in force. Should the parent not wish to take the surrender value, he has the option, after three full years' premiums have been paid, of receiving a Paid-up Policy for such a proportion of the original Sum Assured as the number of payments made bears to the whole number payable. If written application be made and the transaction completed within the days of grace, and provided such proportion be not less than £50.
For Prospectus, Forms of Proposal and all particulars, apply to the STANDARD LIFE OFFICE, STANDARD BUILDINGS, CAIRO.

div.head: REVUE COMMERCIALE
div.p: Cotons.

On a beau être pessimiste et prévoir les pires. des ohoser, quand la peur s'en mêle, les évère- ments vous débordent, et tel a été notre cas pendant la semaine qui vient de finir. Dans notre précédente revue, nous disiona b'en que tout n'était pas fini et qu'il y aurait probable- ment une suite de liquidations, mais en même tempe nous ajoutions que la tendence semblait meilleure; et bien ! nous nous som- mes bel et bien grossièrement trompés en es- pérant trop vite en une reprise ou tout au moins en on arrêt de la baisse.

Il est clairaujourd'hui que les positions étaient beaucoup plus surchargées que ne le disaient les intéressé, et la preuve en est les énormes quantités mises en vente ces jours ci et qui ont fini par produire une vérite ble panique; car on ne saurait appeler autrement ce désarroi de marché et cette baisse de tallari 1 7/16 que nous avons ene et sans qu'aucun fait nouveau et sérieux soit venu la provoquer, en dehors du désir intense manifesté ou de l'obligation peut- être où se sont trouvés quelques détenteurs de contrats Juillet d'en finir avec lent portefeuille, C'était piteux, maisy a-t-il moyen de raisonner avec le spéculateur apeuré !

Le fait est que ce qui semblait probable en Juillet, après l'émission des filières, s'est véri- fié quirs jours plus tôt et devant la tendance on le dispositions si peu encourageantes mon- trées en dernier lieu, on est à se demander si, en fin de compte, nous en avons fini avec la baisse. On se prend à l'espérer, mais sans oser trop y croire, étant donné qu'il y a encore pas mal de Juillet en circulation.
En attendant, voici comment les chores se sont passées pendant la semaine :

Samedi, et contrairement à l'impression lais- sée par la clôture de la veille, la tenue da mar- ché a été faible et les cours ont fini en baisse, et pour les deux jours suivants l'allure a été la même, ce qui a fini par nous valoir une baisse totale pour les trois séances d'on demi tallari. A ce point, l'arrêt paraissait complet et en général on s'attendait à une amélioration quand, pour comble de malheur, l'Amérique nous est venue avec 23 points de baisse. Cette circonstance, non prévue au programme, a augmenté la mauvaise humeur produite par les pronostics peu brillants pour ce qui concer- nait les exportations de la semaine, et sa con- séquence directe a été un nouveau recul de 1/2 de tallari tout à fait à l'ouverture.

Au cours de 20 tallaris il y a en des achats pour compte du commerce, achats qui se sont élévés à un assez joli. chiffres, à en jager par le soulagement tout momentaré qu'on a res- senti le marché. Nous disons tout momen- tané, car, de fait, les cffres de vente qui ont sffluées par la suite ont eu le don peu désiré d'accentuer l'écrasement des cours qui en pea d'instants sont tombés à 19 19/32. La clôture toutefois a eu lieu en reprise à 19 23/32, tant à cause de l'avant bourse de Li- verpool jogée satisfaisante, que de la retraite des vendeurs.

Le lendemain, tout en fluctuant un petit peu, le dit cours de 19 29/32 a pu ê're main tenu et ce matin c'est à ce même nivean que nous avons débuté: mais à l'instar des tonneaux des dansi les qui ne tarissaient jamais, des nouvelles quantités de juillet Finrent encore sur le marché et comme la

dernière heure il y avait une véritable course au clocher à qui vendrait avant son voisin, la clôture a eu lieu à 19 5/16. A ce moment la tendance était si mauvaise que si les affeires avaient duré un quart d'heure de plas, il est presque certain que nous aurions fléchi à 819 et peut-être même au-dessus.
Quoiqu'il en soit, c'est à 19 5/16 que la semaine se termine et dans l'état actuel des choses personne ne se sent assez hardi pour dire ou prévoir ce qui pourrait nous arriver demain.

Cela n'empêche pourtant que raisonnable- ment il est permis de croire à un revirement: Malgré tout, il y a eu de grands allègements et comme en définitive la position statistique n'a pas changé de beaucoup, on peut bien penser, sans trop se risquer dans son apprécia tion, qu'avec de la stabilité dans les cours la consommation n'hésiterait pas à venir aux schats. Les besoins en filature existent et ei celle-ci montre de la réserve,ce n'est qu'à cause de notre faiblesse, le fond des choses étant que les cours actuels doivent être considérés par elle comme attrayants.

Quant aux deux points qui influencent d'une façon, marquée les détenteurs de la vieille ré- colte, soit les petits embarquements et la filière de juillet, au point où neus en sommer, ils de- vraient être envisagés avec un peu plus de calme. Juin était prévu comme mois sans im- portance comparativement au mois correspon- dent en 1905, et la semaine prochaine, sous ce rapport, pourrait bien ne pas être différente des deux qui l'ont précédée; mais, d'autre part, est on sûr qu'il ne s'est rien fait avec le dehors après toute cette baisse pour embarquement juillet Il vrai que pour commencer le dit mois nous aurons à com, arer aves 20.000 balles l'année dernière, mais en somme, tant du chef. des anciens engagements existants,que de celui des nouvelles affaires, la comparaison pourrait bien ne pas être si mauvaise,surtout si l'on tient le moindre compte de la différence entre les ressources des deux an: ées à cette époque. Quant à la question des filières, qui continue à effrayer les intéressés à la hausse, ne tient-on donc pas compte des réalisations qui ont déjà eu liea et qui doivent avoir joliment réduit les quantités en circulation 1 Et n'a-t-on pas, par dessus le marché, la ressource du report sar Août que quelques vendeurs semblent disposés à consentir dans des conditions modé- rées. Cela est ocûteux il est vrai et au fond peut être quelques-uns craignent, de rester jusqu'à la dernière minute à la merci de l'ex- portateur; mais en attendant cela donne trente jours de temps, sans compter qu'à un certain nivean le commerce n'a pas intérêt à voir tomber les cours trop bas, car il lui faut da temps pour écouler le solde de la récolte et il ne pourra jamais y arriver avec un marché constamment désorganisé.
Il y a donc un certain côté de la question à prendre en considération.

La tenue de la nouvelle récolte a éé tout antre que celle de l'ancienne: la fermeté, et quelle fermeté n'a cessé de prévaloir, au point que, malgré la débandade da Juillet, o'est à peine si le Novembre a baissé de 1/32 pendant toute la semaine, le cours de clôture étant de 16 13/16:

Ce fait nous prouve pour le moins deux choses: la première est que tout le monde n'est pas intéressé à la vieille récolte, et que le marché a encore de la vitalité, ce qui est pour le moins consolant pour l'avenir. Nous ne voulors pas par là prêcher la hausse, les prix en eux-mêmes étant assez élevés, mais, entrant dans la saison morte, l'activité n'est
pas à dédaigner et quant à l'avenir ce sera aux récoltes à décider de la marche à suivre.

De la part de la filatore, il n'y a rien à men- tionner, si ce n'est qu'avec la baisse de l'Amé- ricain, la demande a cessé. C'est tout naturel, et il ne faut être grand clerc philosophie pour le comprendre.

Le marché du disponible a été d'un calme, pour ne pas dire d'une nullité, désespérant; mais sur ce sujet nous nous sommes précédem- ment assez expliqués et pour le réstant de la campagne il ne faut plus compter sur grand chose de ce cô 6 là

Quant aux prix, leur établissement devient une véritable difficulté et à proprement parler on les bases maintenant, plus ou moins, sur lee cours des contrats, tout en faisant entrer en ligne de compte les rares transactions qui se font de temps à autre. Pour aujourd'hui, la côte officielle nous montre une baisse de 3/4 pour les classements inférieurs et 1 1/8 tallari pour les qualités livrables contre contrats, pour les Mit Affifi, tandis que pour les provenances Haute Egypte elle signale 3/4 de baisse pour les Goodfair à Good, avec élimination des autres grades qui n'existent plus. Les Abassi aussi, totalement épuisés, ne sont plus coté. Par contre. les Joannovich que l'on peut ache- ter sur le marché, figuraient avec une réduc- tion dans la valeur de 1/4 à 1/2 tallari.

Les exportations de la semaine, pour la troisième fois, ont été une désillusion com- plète et n'ont pas même atteint les petits pronostics donnés au commencement de la semaine. En effet, leur total n'a été que 3,800 balles, contre 9,500 l'année dernière pour la même période et cela justifie un peu l'hési- tation qui est née chez les haussiers pendant la matinée de Mercredi.
Comme stock, il y a réduction de 50,000 cantars dans la différence en moins comparati vement à l'année dernière.

La semaine prochaine ne s'annonce pas trop bien, mais comme nous le disons plus haut, il ne faut pas trop se hâter à se prononcer, la question des prix pouvant encore modifier sensiblement toutes les prévisions que l'on pourrait faire.

Liverpool est retombé dans les 100 balles de ventes en égyptiens et certes de ce côté-là il n'y a rien de satisfaisant ; le cas est pourtant l'opposé pour ce qui concerne les prix qui n'ont reculé que de 1/16 pour le disponible à la cote de 10 9/16, de 9/64 pour le Jain qui est à 10 8/64 et de 4/64 pour le Novembre noté à 845/64.
Le marché du disponible américan a été un peu plus actif et comme prix il gagne 5 points à 6.12. Par contre, les fatars anciens finissent à 582 et les nouveaux à 560, soit un point de baisse.

De Liverpool on écrit que très probable- ment il y aura un syndicat sur les Egyptiens Juillet et Août que quelques maisons améri- caines se sont amusées à vendre à découvert. La réussite ponvait être espérée par le passé, mais, avec la baisse survenue depuis lors sur notre marché, en sera-t-il de même ? Nous en doutons, car on a amplement le temps d'ache- ter d'ici pour livrer là bas.

De New York, on nous a cablé pendant la semaine le rapport de Miss Giles qui estime la condition de la plante à 84%. d'autres sjoutant que la plante est vigoureuse et saine. Mais pour faire le pendant à cela, nous avons eu aussi des dépêches parlant de sé- cheresse et des vers, avec cette addition que le mal aurait été insignifiant.
Le sentiment actuel à New York est pour la baisse.
Graines de Coton
La situation du marché du disponible est toujours la même peu d'arrivages, rarissimes off'sires et cours établis d'après ceux des contrats.
Ceux de cette semaine ont été de P.T. 68 1/2 an maximum et de P.T. 68 au minimum en clôture.
Les exportations sont restées bien en arrière sur les prévisions, mais il y a eu retard pour deox vapeurs qui viendront s'ajouter à la quantité de la semaine prochaine.

En attendant, cette circonstance, se greffant sar la situation du marché cotonnier, est à considérer comme étant la cause du recal du juillet à P.T. 69, après que, à 69 3/4, il semblait disposé à hausser.
Affaires très modérées en vieille récolte.
La nouvelle, par contre, reste ferme et relati- vement active, clôturant à 63 1/4, après un maximum de 63 1/2 dans le courant de la semaine. La spéculation s'y intéresse chaque jour davantage.
Hull a payé £6. 12/6 da Jain, mais de nou- veau elle semble réservée.
Le Novembre Janvier conserve au contraire sa valeur de £ 6. 2/6.
Feves.

Quelques arrivages et quelques affaires en disponible à P.T. 125, c'est tout ce qu'il y a à signaler. Pour les contrats nous sommes tombés de P.T. 140 à 125, mais pour nous relever à 129-131 à la suite de quelques petites demandes. Rares transactions.

div.head: CHRONIQUE FINANCIERE
div.p: Alexandrie, le 22 Juin.
Cette semaine financière nous a apporté des marchés toujours empreints d'indécision, mais quand même meilleurs que ceux de la semaine dernière.
Lund, ouverture assez ferme, le marché clôture en bonne tendance.
Mardi, la tendance à la hausse qui s'était manifestée la veille s'accentue, le marché est ferme.
Mercredi, le marché ouvre assez ferme, con- tinue en bonne tendance et, sur de grosses réalisation, clôture en baisse.
Jeudi, à peu de choses près même marché que la veille: une cloture faible, suit ane bonne ouverture.

Les marchés de cette semaine sont venue confirmer nos prévisions, il serait oiseux de prétendre maintenant à une reprise, bien plus. de gros spéculateurs jetteraient, paralt-il, un nombre considerable de titres sur le marché, dans l'espoir de les acheter à bien meilleur compte encore au cours de la saison. Que les valeurs baissent, poar certaines cela est possible; mais pour d'autres elle ont atteint maintenant le point auquel elles stationneront durant l'été ; il suffit de jetter les yeux sur le tableau des fluctuations des cours de la semaine pour s'en rendre compte.

Les grosses valeurs sont stationnaires; ni hausse, ni dépréciation, seule, quelques titres sans importance sont encore échangés. La corbeille devient de jour en jour moins animée, les rangs des courtiers s'éclaircissent, de tempsà autres quelques échanges s'opèrent, mais pres- que sans bruit ; on sent que le marché marque de souffle.
A Paris et a Londres, la tension persiste;nous oroyons utile de donner à nos lecteurs un ap perçu des différents marchés européens que publisit hier un de nos confrères du Caire:

France-La liquidation du 15 juin a com- mencé par la réponse des primer, et la journée s'est signalée par un tassement de la cote pro- voqué par le bruit mis en circulation que l'argent, pour les reports sera plus tenda que précédemment. C'est là un fait qui n'a rien de bien surprenant en lui-même. La fin du semes- tre n'est pas sans occasionner, en effet, comme de coutume, des besoins spéciaux. D'autre part on tient, comme d'ordinaire, à conserver de fortes disponibilités en raison de la grosse échéance de coupons du 1er juillet.
Allemagne-La dépense totale inscrite aux budgets allemands est 6.800 millions de marks dont 2.400 milions pour l'Empire et 4.400 millions pour les Etats confédérés.
Une tension est de nouveau apparue sur le marché monétaire; l'escompte libre a des tendances à s'élever.

Le commerce maritime de Hambourg est toujours en progrès. En 1905, l'importation par mer a été de 2.866 millions de marks, contre 2.555 millions, en 1904; l'exportation a été de 2.345 millions, contre 2.147.
Angleterre.-La situation monétaire est res- tée sans changement: on ne croit pas à une diminution du taux de l'escompte.
Pour les cinq premiers mois de l'année, les importations, comparées à celles de la même période de 1905, ont augmenté de 15.6%.
Belgique. Le marché à terme a été mou- vementé, toute la semaine, surtout sur les fonds espagnols qui ont clôturé fermes.
Les valeurs de traction sont restées bien tenues aussi,

Les marchés du fer et de la houille accusent toujours une grande fermeté. On s'attend à une augmentation du prix du charbou. Espagne. La arise ministérielle est ré- solue: peu de ministres ont été remplacés.
A la Bourse de Madrid on a essayé de reve nir à la hausse, après la liquidation, mais sans grand entrain.
La lotte continue toujours autour de la question du tarif douanier sans qu'on puisse présager si la balance va pencher pour l'augmentation ou la diminution.
Italie. La déclaration ministérielle du nouveau Cabinet a été approuvée par une grosse majorité.
On ne sait rien quant au projet de conver sion de la Rente, sinon que M, Luzzatti, chargé des négociations, est parti pour Paris. La Bourse de Rome a des tendances meil- leures.
Dans les onze premiers mois de l'année les recettes da Trésor ont été de 1.421,810.075 lire, en augmentation de 82.008 726 lire, sur la même période de l'exercice précédent.

Il resulte du rapport du Conseil d'adminis tration de la Société Anonyme des Eaux de Tantah que les bénéfices de cette société pour l'exercice 1905 sont de LE. 4.122.395. Ces bénéfices seront repartis comme suit: Reserve statutaire L.B. 906.120
(La reserve statutaire se trouve ainsi porté à L.B. 649.307.) Dividende total de 6 1/2 shell- ings aux actions de Lat. 5 chacune, non amorties, soit 6 1/2 %
... 8710.289.3 Dividende de 1 1/2 shelling aux actions de jouissance. Dividende de P.T. 7 8/10 à cha- oune de 3000 parts de ton- dation
Conseil d'Administration Report à nouveau ...
Report: Dividende sequis aux actions
D'autre part l'Assemblée, à l'unanimité, ap- prouvant la répartition des bénéfices proposée
par le Conseil d'Administration, fixe les dividendes comme suit:
Pour chaque action de Capital (c. a. d. non amortie de Let. 5 versées): intérêt et dividende 6 1/2 shell. (soit 6 1/2 %).
Pour chaque action de Jouissance: 11/2 hell.
Pour chaque part de Fondation: P.T. 7 8/10.
Le président, au nom du Conseil, déclare que ces dividendes seront mis en paiement à partir da 11 juin 1905.

div.head: "WHAT'S IN A NAME?"
div.p: The spirit of the phi'osopher's question as to "what's in name?" is evoked by a case now before the French courts. The question is one between a duke of ancient name, and a variety artist, one Mdlle. Jarre, who has given herself the stage name of "De Trevise." The plaintiff nobleman is the Duke de Trevise, and seeing his family name loudly billed as that of a lady appearing in an act entitled "Fleur de Peau," all his pride of pedigree and place took ambrage. He moved the court on Tuesday to prohibit the patting of the cognomen De Trevise to such base uses. The judges have taker & week to consider the questions involved.

div.head: GERMAN ENTERPRISE IN TURKEY.
div.p: It is stated in Berlin that Germany has obtained the firman at Constantinople from the Ottoman Post and Telegraph Department, in favour of the Deustche Seekabelwerken Noldenham, an offshoot of the cable between Sid-el-Bahr and the Isle of Imbros. For months past an English company has attempted to secure this contract, but the terms sub- mitted by the Garman company were so much more to the advantage of the Administration that the contract was secured without any difficulty at the finish. The same German undertaking was entrusted last year with the inception of the Kustendje-Constantinople cab'e, and has therefore gained a solid footing in the Near East.

div.head: SCIATICA AND KIDNEY DISEASE.
div.p: Patient Wheeled About in a Bath-Chair for 3 Months.
Specialist Declared Her Incurable.

Mr. Henry Boxer, living at 33 Westlake Road, Rotherhithe, London, England, writes:- Gentlemen,-I feel I must write and thank you for the great good my wife is deriving from Doan's Backache Kidney Pills. This time last year she was so ill with sciatics and kidney disease that she entirely lost the use of her limbs, and was unable to stand. I had to carry her about the house like a baby. The doctor said that if I did not get her out of London I should not have her very long, so I got her down to Sheerness to some of her re- lations, who were very kind to her. She was wheeled about in a bath chair for three months, and although the change of air did her gcod, she was still unable to walk when she returned home. I made her a pair of crutches, which improved matters a little, and at this time friend advised as to try Doan's Backache Kidney Pills. I got some for my wite, and she seemed better after the second or third box, so she persevered with the medicine, and ever since then she has made good headway. She does not get the awfal pains in the back, and she is quite another woman. I have got her 30 boxes of Doan's Pills altogether, and her remarkable cure is the talk of the neighbourhood.
"Bither of us will be only too glad to speak for Doan's Backache Kidney Pills any time, and you are welcome to publish this letter.-I am, gentlemen, gratefully yours,

HY. BOXER. Some months after receiving this letter, we sent our representative to see Mrs. Boxer. "I am still in splendid health to-day," the grateful woman raid, "and can get about the house nicely, as well as help with the housework. I still use Doan's Pills occasionally, for I find they keep me in such good health."

Yee," Mr. Boxer joined in, "and I wouldn't like to be without a box of Doan's Pills in the house, for they have saved my wife's life. Since I wrote you last, she has been down to Sheerness again, but, thank goodness, not to be wheeled about in a bathohsir, for she can walk as well as anyone, and our relations in Sheerness are astonished at her cure. Before she used Doan's Pills, no one thought she would live, and for nine months she was unable to leave her bed. A specialist in kidney troubler, who had her oase in hand, said to me: "I don't like to tell you, but there's not the slightest hope of your wife pulling through; her disease is one that nothing can cure.' A local doctor, too, said: "It's no use my coming to see your wife any more; I can only give her the same medicine over and over again, and I can never o her any good; she is past a cure."

"However, I wouldn't give up hope, and I kept trying different medicines until I heard of Doan's Pills. Before my wife had finished the third box the seemed going right ahead, improving quickly, and she has been well, as you see her to-day, for a long time Words cannot tell you how grateful we are for the happiness Doan's Backache Kidney Pille have brought to our home."

Doan's Dinner Pills are sold by all chemists and draggists at P.T. 13 per box, or P.T. 71 for six boxes; or they may be bought direct from the general agent for Egypt. Max Fischer, Mousky Street, Cairo.

This is a condition (or disease) to which doctors give many names, but which few of them really understand. It it simply weakness—a break-down, as it were, of the vital forces that sustain the system. No matter what may be its causes (for they are almost numberless), its symptoms are much the same; the more prominent being sleeplessness, sense of prostration or weariness, depression of spirits and want of energy for all the ordinary affairs of life. Now, what alone is absolutely essential in all such cases is increased vitality—vigour--

Le Crédit Lyonnais fait toutes opérations de banque, telles que:
Ouverture de comptes courants contre dépôts de valeurs;
Emission de traites et chèques, émission de lettres de Crédit, paiement par télégraphe sur les principales villes de la France et de l'étranger;
Garde de titres;
Recourvement d'effets sur l'Egypte et l'étranger;
Le Crédit Lyonnais reçoit des fonds ou un compte de dépôt et délivre des bons à échéance fixe aux taux suivants:
2% aux bons de 1 an et au-delà.

div.head: Supplement Commercial et Financier.
div.p: De "L'Egyptian Gazette"

Le Supplément Commercial et Financier de l' "Egyptian Gazette" paraît chaque Samed à midi, de façon à pouvoir être expédié par le paquebot autrichien. Il contient des revues complètes et impartiales du coton, des graines de coton, et du marché des valeurs; les dernières statistiques jusqu'à la veille de sa publication: des tableaux des fluctuations de la place et les copies des dépêches officielles envoyées à la Liverpool Cotton Association, etc etc
L'abonnement pour une année en Egypte coûte 1 L.E. y compris les frais de poste; pour l'étranger 10 P.T. de port en sus.
